node.text:
Fighting Battles

Pvt. Trent Maness, a Marine with Charlie Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, talks about his experience with cancer and his journey to become a United States Marine on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C., July 29. 2021.

(U.S. Marine Corps Video by Sgt. Yamil Casarreal)

node.text:
Recruits with Alpha Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, and Oscar Company, 4th Recruit Training Battalion, complete the basic events of swim qualification on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C. July 20, 2021. 

Recruits are required to pass swim qualification to graduate from recruit training. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.title: Alpha and Oscar Companies Swim Qualification

node.text: Sgt. Matthew Rearick, a Recruiter with Recruiting Station Frederick, Md., and his younger brother Pvt. Marc Rearick share not only the bond of brotherhood but also the title Marine. Matthew recruited his younger brother once Marc expressed interest in joining. (U.S. Marine Corps Video by Lance Cpl. Ryan Hageali)

node.text:
Recruits with Mike Company, 3rd Recruit Training Battalion, prepare and perform chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) defense training at Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C. July 06, 2021. Training for CBRN defense is an event in which recruits experience the exposure of gasses and learn how to properly use a gas mask. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.text:
Master Sgt. Hyuk Kim, with the Republic of Korea Marine Corps, discusses his time at drill instructor school and the history of cooperation between the R.O.K. Marine Corps and the U.S. Marine Corps aboard Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island S.C., June 23, 2021. Kim graduated from the course on June 25, 2021. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Cpl. Daniel Johnson)

node.text:
Two years after he first stepped on the yellow footprints, Pfc. Nathaniel Mensahsimms, with India Company, 3rd Recruit Training Battalion, returned to Parris Island determined to complete swim qualification and earn his Eagle, Globe and Anchor. 

Mensahsimms tells the story of how he wanted to make his dad proud by returning to boot camp and becoming a Marine. He graduated from recruit training on June 25, 2021.

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.text:
Not all wounds are visible. This month is a time to remember that post-traumatic stress disorder can affect anyone, and can be caused by any traumatic event. 

If you are struggling with PTSD, seek help. Visit the National Center for PTSD at The link doesn’t work, VA resources can be found here: https://www.ptsd.va.gov/gethelp/crisis_help.asp for support.

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Christopher McMurry)

node.text:
This Memorial Day may we remember those who have given the ultimate sacrifice for our nation and the legacies they each left behind.

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Sgt. Yamil Casarreal and LCpl. Michelle Brudnicki/Released)

Chaplains of Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island continued to adapt and overcome the challenges of Covid-19 in order to continue to provide religious services to the personnel aboard the depot. 

(U.S. Marine Corps Video by Lance Cpl. Christopher McMurry)

node.text:
Pvt. Nicholas Probus with Papa Company, 4th Recruit Training Battalion, graduated recruit training with the memory of his late friend, Kaleb Woolen in his heart. 

He tells the story of how the two became friends and how Kaleb impacted his decision of becoming a Marine.

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.text:
Cpl. Noah Flowe, a Primary Marksmanship Instructor with Weapons and Field Training Battalion, teaches marksmanship fundamentals to recruits with Charlie Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, aboard Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C., March 11, 2021. 

Recruits spend a week learning and practicing marksmanship fundamentals before shooting live rounds the following week. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Randall Whiteman)

node.text:
Korean War veteran James Craig retells his story of a gruesome battle upon Stromboli Hill while fighting the Chinese army in 1952. Craig is a two-time Purple Heart Recipient and served with Fox Co., 2nd Bn., 1st MAR., 1st MARDIV.

(Historic items provided courtesy of Stephen Price)

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Cpl. Shane Manson)

node.text:
Fighting Battles

Pvt. Trent Maness, a Marine with Charlie Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, talks about his experience with cancer and his journey to become a United States Marine on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C., July 29. 2021.

(U.S. Marine Corps Video by Sgt. Yamil Casarreal)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Parris Island on August 04, 2021. May be an image of bus and outdoors.

node.text:
From the Classroom to the Footprints

Educators from along the east coast arrive at the yellow footprints on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C., Aug. 4, 2021.
 
Educators are brought down to Parris Island for the Educator's Workshop, in which teachers learn about the process of recruit training to better understand and support their students who are interested in joining the Marine Corps. 

(U.S. Marine Corps photo by Lance Cpl. Michelle Brudnicki)

node.text:
Brother By Blood and Title

When Matthew Rearick was growing up, the furthest thing from his mind was joining the military. Now, eight years later, Sgt. Rearick says he credits the Marine Corps with changing his life for the better, and he has inspired his little brother, Pvt. Marc Rearick, to follow in his footsteps and become a United States Marine.

Check out the Rearick brothers' story on our Facebook page!

(U.S. Marine Corps story and photos by Lance Cpl. Ryan Hageali)

node.text:
The Parris Island Shooting Team presented their awards to Brig. Gen. Julie L. Nethercot, commanding general of Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, on July 29, 2021.

The Parris Island Shooting Team competes nationally at military and civilian marksmanship competitions to bring back shooting knowledge and enhance their marksmanship.

(U.S. Marine Corps photos by Lance Cpl. Michelle Brudnicki)

node.text:
Recruits with Alpha Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, and Oscar Company, 4th Recruit Training Battalion, complete the basic events of swim qualification on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C. July 20, 2021. 

Recruits are required to pass swim qualification to graduate from recruit training. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Parris Island on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, people playing musical instruments and indoor.

node.text:
The Parris Island Marine Band, with Headquarters and Service Battalion, performed during the annual Beaufort Water Festival, in Beaufort, S.C., July 16, 2021. 

The annual Beaufort Water Festival has been celebrated since 1956. 

(U.S. Marine Corps photos by Lance Cpl. Ryan Hageali and Lance Cpl. Marcel Gorka)

node.text:
“I hope to get the opportunity to go to OCS. I want to be the reason why most Marines stay in and as an officer I hope to accomplish that.”

Sgt. Michael Longo, a Primary Marksmanship Instructor on Parris Island, is following his goal of becoming a Marine Corps officer through the Marine Enlisted Commissioning Program (MECEP). 

Learn about his story from being inspired to join to becoming a leader of Marines by checking out our Facebook page. 

(U.S. Marine Corps photos and Story by Sgt. Yamil Caserreal)

node.text: Sgt. Matthew Rearick, a Recruiter with Recruiting Station Frederick, Md., and his younger brother Pvt. Marc Rearick share not only the bond of brotherhood but also the title Marine. Matthew recruited his younger brother once Marc expressed interest in joining. (U.S. Marine Corps Video by Lance Cpl. Ryan Hageali)

node.text:
War Paint

Recruits with Charlie Company, 1st Recruit Training Battalion, and November Company, 4th Recruit Training Battalion, pose for a photo after a cover and concealment class on Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C. July 11, 2021. 

The class taught recruits how to apply the three basic patterns of individual camouflage: splotching, striping, and splotching and striping. 

(U.S. Marine Corps photos by Sgt. Dana Beesley and Lance Cpl. Ryan Hageali)

node.text:
Recruits with Mike Company, 3rd Recruit Training Battalion, prepare and perform chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) defense training at Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C. July 06, 2021. Training for CBRN defense is an event in which recruits experience the exposure of gasses and learn how to properly use a gas mask. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Godfrey Ampong)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Parris Island on July 13, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and outdoors.

node.text:
Smoke and Mud

Recruits with Kilo Company, 3rd Recruit Training Battalion, complete the Day Movement Course during Basic Warrior Training aboard Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island, S.C., July 8, 2021. 

Basic Warrior Training is a one week-long training event that teaches recruits the basics of combat survival and rifle maneuvers. 

(U.S. Marine Corps photos by Cpl. Samuel C. Fletcher and Lance Cpl. Christopher McMurry)
